div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.

FRIDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1907..

div.head: MAKING A WAR.
div.p: The American papers say that it their fleet goes to the Pacific it means war.

The New York "San," on Sept. 29, wrote thus :-"Mr. Roosevelt has reaffirmed his intention of sending the entire effective naval force of this country to the Pacific Ocean, and simultaneously the General Board has delivered to Mr. Metcalf its recommendations for an increase of the navy. The two facts are vitally Borrelated. Those who apparently have the right to express authoritative explanations of the object of the transferring of the navy to the Western ocean persist in saying that it is for practice. We regret to say that we share the Japanese belief that the explanation is false. The navy is going to the Pacific Ocean for war with Japan, and Japan recognises the fast and is energetically preparing for it. Once the operation of transferring our ships to Pacific waters has been accomplished, what is inevitable. It is an insane project.

The American people do not want to go to war with Japan or with any other country, but the American people are apparently without recourse or voice. There is little or no hope that Congress will dare to oppose the President's plans. It is one of the most serious situations that have confronted this country, and the only mitigating consideration we are able to discern is that the activity of the Navy Departments, and of the War Department too, at this present moment indicative of full sense of the gravity of the impending crisis." The "New York Times" devotes an entire 1 page to the discussion of America's answer to the attitude of Japan," and "the sudden cessation of pin-pricks when Tokio learned that the armada was to be moved to the Pacific."

"Is the Press of the United States going insane" asks the "Times". New York correspondent, who sends this news. "It is no use trying to minimise the gravity of its attitude or its ability to stir up trouble. We know pretty well by now what was the real cause of the Spanish-American war and the man who among all Americans was chiefly responsible for it. A letter from Mr. William Randolph Hearst is in existence, and was printed in a magazine not long ago. It was to an artist whom he had sent to Cubs, and who reported no likelihood of war. Mr. Hearst instructed him to stay. You provide the pictures, he wrote, I'll provide the war."

Mr. Taft, the American Secretary for War, speaking at a banquet at Tokyo on Oct. 1, said :- "There is only a little cloud over our friendship of fifty years, and the greatest earthquake of the century could not shake our amity." Mr. Taft declared that the San Fran cinco affair could be finally and honourably adjusted through diplomatic channels. War between Japan and the United States would be a crime against civilization. Neither of the two peoples wanted it, and both Governments would strain every nerve to prevent a conflict. Mr. Taft characterised as infamous the attempts which the newspapers were largely responsible. In conclusion, he told his hearers that they could rest assured that America's goodwill towards Japan was as cordial as ever.

Referring to the fact that he had been honoured with a second invitation to have an audience of the Emperor, Mr. Taft said that he felt it was due to the desire of his Majesty to send a message of good will to the Americans and to show the world that Japan was friendly to the United States. The speech created a splendid apression.

div.head: Police Budget
div.p: 4 thefts, 9 misdemeanours, and 43 contraventions have occurred in Cairo during the Last 24 hours.

div.head: Astro-Hungarian Agency
div.p: Dr. Wagner and the staff of the AustroHungarian Agonoy have returned to Cairo for the winter season.

div.head: Remarkable Phenomenom.
div.p: A negress in the Egyptian Sadan has just given birth to twins, one of which is perfectly black and the other white.

div.head: National Bank
div.p: It is reported that Mr. Naggiar, Chief Cashier of the National Bank, Cairo, has handed in his resignation.

div.head: The Egyptian University.
div.p: The total subscriptions collected up to date for the project of the Egyptian university amount to L.E. 26,482.

div.head: The Love Affair
div.p: M. Samuel Levy, ex-assistant cashier of the National Bank, is being sent for trial before the Aix Court. He will leave Egypt to-day by the M.M. mail boat.

div.head: Ministry of Education
div.p: The Superior Council of Public Instruction will meet on the 14th instant to consider a project authorising students to be examined in Arabic for the Secondary Education Certificate.

div.head: Italian Orphanage.
div.p: The Italian Benevolent Society of Cairo is contemplating the foundation of an orphanage. Subscriptions are to be asked for and it is proposed to build the orphanage at Abbassich.

div.head: Mohamed All School.
div.p: The Mohamed Ali industrial school, which has been built at Chatby to commemorate the Mohamed Ali centenary, will be inaugurated next month, when the Khedive and Ministers will attend.

div.head: Mosque Hygiene.
div.p: The Public Health Department have submitted to the Council of Ministers proposals concerning the sanitary condition of mosques, and after passing the Ministers they will be submitted to the Legislative Council.

div.head: International Judicial Conference,
div.p: The International Judicial Conference will resume its meetings in November under the precedence of Boutros Pasha Ghali. At its first injection the question of reforming the Bourse regulations in Cairo and Alexandria will be considered.

div.head: A Fatal slip
div.p: While Abdel Hamid Said, servant to Ibrahim Bey Hamdy, was washing vegetables, at the Ismailia Canal bank, his foot slipped and fell into the water and was drowned. His body was recovered and sent to the hospital prior to interment.

div.head: Court Martial.
div.p: A court martial will assemble in Cairo under the presidency of Colonel Gilson Bey tomorrow morning for the trial of Adjutant Major Mohamed Ef. Yongof, and Ljent. Mohamed Ef Tewfik, both of the Works Department, Ministry of War.

div.head: The Brindisi Mall
div.p: The mail for Europe via Port Snid and Brindisi will be made up at the G.P.O. Alexandrin, at 315 p.m. on Sunday 13th for ordinary correspondence, 2.10 p.m. for registered correspondence, midday for money orders and insured articles and at 6 p.m. on Saturday 12th for parcels

div.head: Map of the Delta
div.p: A new map of the Delta and of the Fayoum as far as Beni Suef has been issued by the Survey Department. This map, which is primarily intended for the nse of schools, etc. is printed in Arabic, and is divided to shew the position and extent of each particular market. We understand that similar maps, printed in colours, will be produced of the whole of the valley of the Nile ne farm Assonance before the end of the year.

div.head: Cairo Drainage.
div.p: Mr. Carkett James, Director General of the Drainage Department has returned from Europe and has already completed his project on the drainage of the Capital, which he will submit for the approval of Sir William Garstin on his return from Europe. However, the execution of the project depends on the attitude of the Powers in regard to the proposed increase in house tax in Cairo in order to meet the expenses entailed by the project.

div.head: The Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: On the 14th inst. the Gemma Caimimi Italian dramatic company will make its vidébut at the New Alhambra Theatre, Alexandria, under the direction of Signor Ethore Berti. The repertoire of the company will include "L'Aiglon," "Apparenza," "La Culla," "Alfredo de Masset," " principe consorte," "Casa d'Argillo," "Eidelberga mia" "Uma moglie onesta," "Monsieur Beaucaire," "Il Metodo," "Niente di dazio," "La Rafale.” On the opening night Sardon's fascinating four act drama "Odette" will be played.

div.head: British Gambling Hell.
div.p: he Cairo police made a raid on a gambling hell in the Esbekieh Quarter on Wednesday Thorning. The proprietor was thought to be Greek, but on the entrance of the police he produced papers proving him to be a British Subject. Later in the morning the police force returned with the cavass of the British Con. slate and an entrance was made. Sixteen poker tables were found and round a baccarat table were standing 44 persons. The names of one persons were taken and some of them are said to be well-known merchants.

div.head:
Egyptian Politics
ROBERTSON AND KAMEL
div.p: A London correspondent writes :

I understand that Mustapha Pasha Kamel is no longer to enjoy any support from Mr. J. M. Robertson, M.P. This severance has been brought about owing to the same reasons which have led to the present dissensions among the Nationalists in Egypt, for it has become evident that the Pasha is seeking to make the Nationalist movement subserve first and last the cause of his personal ascendency.

The manner in which the organ of Mustapha Pasha Kamel has of date attacked Hafiz Awad has produced a very bad impression among the section of Radicals who were inclined to support the Pasha. These proceedings are attracting some attention and in a letter from Cairo of September 15th the correspondent of the "Times” gave a snooinot account of the controversy, from which I extract the following:

"Jealous of any encroachment on the prero.. gatives of their creator, Mustapha Kamel Pasha's degans have assailed Hafia Awad in unmeasured terins, accusing him of inconsistency and self-seeking, and of falsely claiming to be the originator of his programme and the representative or delegate of the National movement. That he should go to London," says the "Egyptian Standard," "and seek notoriety is a right we cannot deny him. But that he should do so at the expense of other people and by pawning (sic) off other people's Ideas as his own is a questionable procedure and one that he will have to repent upon his return to Cairo. ..."

Such glimpses into the dissensions of the Nationalists, have caused a disagreeable impres. sion and it is considered that the organs of Mustapha Pasha Kamel are to be blamed for having initiated such tactics Under these circumstances it is not to be wondered if Mr. Robertson has decided to have no longer any relations with Mustapha Pasha Kamel

div.head: LIBERAL PARTY AND SIR E GORST.
div.p: The following are the terms of a telegram sent to "Al Mokattam" by Mohamed Bey Wahid, leader of the Liberal movement in Egypt, in welcome to Sir Eldon Gorst on his return to Egypt:-

The whole valley of the Nile rejoices over the happy return of Sir Eldon Goret to Kasr el Doubara, for it knows that through him the son of true civilisation is on the ascendant as well as the benign light of the great and absolute liberty and permanent prosperity which their good deeds spread over Egypt and the Egyptians. The Liberals welcome the arrival of Sir Eldon and hope that by his wisdom he will succeed in gratifying the wishes of the devoted Egyptians, and that he will safeguard the country from the misdeeds of those who desire its ruin."

Nachat Rey, one of the foremost leaders of the Egyptian Liberal Party, has quite recovered from the ophthalmic complaint from which he has been suffering and is preparing to enter the arena of party politics by the side of Mohamed Bey Wahid.

div.head: "EGYPT"
div.p: The English monthly magazine, "Egypt", which was to have appeared last month, has still to make its début. The promoters intend issuing it in the course of this month and will initiate a vigorous campaign in favor of immediate evacuation.

div.head: KAMEL TOUCHED
div.p: Mustapha Pasha Kamel announces through his newspaper that he has been greatly touched" by a "touching letter" written by one hundred and twelve notables of the Rebera province assuring him of their entire approval of his policy.

div.head:
OBITUARY.
BISHP OF BEYROUT.
div.p: We regret to learn of the death of Mgr. Joseph Dibes, Maronite Bishop of Beyront and Ain. Sula, which occurred on the 5th inst. at his residence at Ain-Sada Beyront.

The late Bishop was born in 1838 and gradinated in Ain Warakn-School; he was then made * Dencon, and in 1872 was elected Bishop to Beyront, where he rendered valuable services to his sect by establishing a printing office; the College de la Sagesse, which contains now about 300 students, a girls' school, and many churches, among which is the magnificent Cathedral which was lately built at Beyrout at the cost of not less than £25,000.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The S.S. "Egyptian" of the Westcott and Laurance linie left Malta to-day and is due here next Monday with general cargo from London and coals from Newcastle.
The Ellerman liner "Sardinia" sailed from Liverpool yesterday for Gibraltar, Malta, and Alexandria with a general cargo.

div.head: THE Hotel Casino San Stefano
div.p: Will be open during Winter
REDUCED PRICES

div.head:
THE SCHOOL OF AGRICULTURE
NO ALLOWANCE MADE
div.p: With reference to a parliamentary question by Mr. Robertson, M.P., respecting the Egyptian School of Agriculture, Mr. Ronald Graham reports that no arrangement has been made to DAY monthly allowance to any student in that school, whatever his qualifications. All students pay the school fees, according to the school, and no subsidies have ever been paid to them. The number of applications for admission to the school for the coming school year is greater that in any previous year. Of the applicants, 47 possess the primary certificate and 18 hold no certificate at all. No holder of a secondary certificate has applied for admission to the school.
A list is annexed showing the number of candidates entering the school from 1900 to 1907.

Mr. Graham adds that Mr. Robertson's question is evidently founded on a misapprehension. He has, apparently, confused the regulations for admission with the financial conditions which prevail for those who, after a four years' course, have gained the diploma in Agriculture.
Candidates entering the School of Agriculture from 1900-1907

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive accompanied by the Governor attended midday prayers at the Mosque of Sidi Yacoub.

div.head: LORD CROMER AND THE FREEDOM OF THE CITY.
div.p: The freedom of the City of London, which is to be bestowed upon Lord Cromer on the last Monday of the month, will be opelosed in what is colloquially called a "gold box" of the usual hundred-guinea type. This casket says, "Modern Society," will comprise designs recalling the art of ancient Egypt, and will also symbolise the new Egypt which has been called into being by the exertions of the great Agent General during his many years of patient service in Cairo. The event is arousing much enthusiasm in civil circles, and it will be the last great function of the Mayoralty of Sir William Treloar. A large number of invitations are to be sent out, and there is an idea of anticipating the glories of Lord Mayor's Day at the end of the following week by putting up some of the street decorations and bringing on the City's illuminations in honor of the day.

If this is carried out, the hub of the universe will present an unusually festive appearance for more than a fortnight, because the decorative features of November 9th will remain until the following Wednesday, which is the day accepted by the German Emperor for his own second visit to the Guildhall. Fifteen years ago His Imperial Majesty received at the hands of the Lord Mayor of the day a gold box of the value of 250 guineas, a sum which has been exceeded on two occasions only. A box of the value of £275 was offered to King Edward at about the time of his marriage, and many years afterwards the late Emperor of Russia received a hox valued at £337. It is rather anomalous to remember that Muzaffer: 1 ed-Din, the late Shah of Persia, and his predecessor received between them gold boxes of the value of 500 guineas.

div.head:
EGYPT'S MEAT SUPPLY
THE BUTCHERS' COMPLAINTS
div.p: The Cairo butchers at the present time are complaining that the regulations regards the closing of the markets and the restrictions on the transport of cattle are seriously damaging their business. But these regulations have been laid down by the Board of Health for the general well-being of the country and it isb impossible that the interests of the entire I population should be set aside because these restrictions injuriously affect the trail of a single class. It would be the height of foolishness to allow cattle from abroad, which are infected to be taken to Cairo without let or hindrance. The import into Egypt of Servian cattle is by way of Salonica, which is an infected port. The large cattle importers should bring the cattle through Constanza, which is immune. If they made use of the Roumanian port as the point of departure for Egypt, the Government might possibly see its way to allow the unrestricted import of Servian cattle to the slaughterhouses of the interior. As long, however, as Salonica remains infected, careful restrictions must be enforced.

Salonica will probably always be infected. It is a Turkish port and the authorities do not exercise any effective control over the cattle plague. Of course it is a very convenient port for the export of cattle to this country as it is in direct communication by rail with Servia and far nearer to Egypt than Constanza, but as long as the Ottoman sanitary authorities remain indifferent the Quarantine Board at Alexandria must exercise great discrimination in regard to the cattle arriving here from the Macedonian port.
The grumbling of the butchers at the import of frozen meat may be quite disregarded as it is solely based on selfish interests.

We are informed that a deputation consisting of Mr. Desposito, Mr. Zender, Mr. Trinkidis, Mr Dejean, Mr. Stelio Bulga, Mr. Stamati, Cheilk Fargalli, and Mr. John B. Caffari, the Managing Director of Caffari's Co-Operative Markets Ltd. were invited to attend a meeting held yesterday morning at the hend office of the Sanitary Department to discuss with Dr. Graham Bey, Colonel Carner, and Mr. Littlewood, the matter concerning the difficulties in obtaining sufficient quantity of cattle for the Cairo consumption.

A petition had been submitted a few days ago to the sanitary authorities requesting the reopening of certain markets in Upper Egypt and to permit the importation of foreign cattle. The officials having studied this very im. portant matter, have been able to give satisfaction to the members of the deputation, and thus avoided a general strike of the butchers, which would have greatly inconvenienced the entire population of Cairo. The deputation Before retiring 'expressed their thanks to Dr. Graham Bey, Colonel Garner, and Mr. Little wood for the kind reception accorded and the promises made.

div.head: HELLENIC SCHOOLS.
div.p: This morning the scholastic year of the Hellenio community's schools at Alexandria began after the summer holiday. Monsignor Theofanis Moschonas, Metropolitan of the Thebaid, and Vicar representative of the Patriarch, conducted a service. The boy's school has been considerably enlarged and all through the summer a large staff of workmen have been employed on the construction. An extra storey on the left side of the big quadrangle has been created and a number of new class-rooms added. On the ground floor there are seven large class-rooms for elementary education, each room being seven by nine metres. The mess room is fourteen by twelve metres. Ten' bath-rooms and a number of lavatories, eto.. have been constructed and also a sitting room for the staff of teachers. On the first floor three class-rooms, forty two metres square each, have been built for the drawing and commercial department, and five other rooms, nine by seven metres square for the higher classes. On this floor also are a private room for the headmaster and a sitting room for the teachers and class rooms for instruction in science and music. The playground has been considerably enlarged and is now sixty two metres in length and nineteen breadth. All along the first floor runs a balcony, ninety five metres in length. The architecture was entrusted to the Greek engineer of Alexandria, Mr. George Lozinas, who is also the architect of the Benachi Orphanage, the Salvago Polytechnic, the Zervudnchi Elementary Schools, and the Free Kitchen of Mrs. Benachi. Cavalliere Diananti is the contractor. The cost of enlarging the boys school was L.E. 7,000 and it is now one of the largest colleges in Egypt. Last year there were 1,271 boys and 1,000 girls attending these schools.

div.head: THE SUDAN BUDGET.
div.p: The annual work of framing the Sudan Budget for the forthcoming year, a task which usually occupies from a month to six weeks time has commenced at the Financial Offices of the Government in Cairo. We learn that is orlikely that there will be any departures from the ordinary routine usually followed in the allocation of monies to the various departments.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL, CAIRO.
div.p: Strictly family Hotel. Built in 1904. near h Railway Station Electric Light. Lift.
Sanitary arrangements up to-date. Open all the year round. Special terms for Government officials and Army of Occupation
29242-26-11-90 J. VOCLES, Propr. Manager.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: TheSirdar, Sir Reginald Wingate Pasha, will return to Alexandria tomorrow to have an audience with the Khedive and to inspect the Egyptian Garrison of Alexandria.
Mr. Dupuis, Acting Adviser to the Ministry of Public Works, will proceed to Khartoum at the end of this month.
Mr. Perry, Under Secretary of State at the Ministry of Public Works, Towns and Buildings Department, is laid up at his house in Cairo.
Baron Selig de Kusel Bey has left London for Egypt and is expected to arrive in Cairo on the 16th inst.
Colonel J. M. Jones, A.M.S., having report ed his arrival in Egypt, is taken on the strength of the Army of Occupation and has taken over the duties of P.M.O. and Officer Commanding R.A.M.C.
Miraloi E.V. Turper Bey, director of Sudan Posts and Telegraphs, is returning to Khartoum to-morrow.
Ali Bey Hussein has been appointed inspector in the Ministry of Public Instruction.
Dr. H. Engel has returned to Helouan from Europe after attending medical meetings at Vienna and Dresden, at which the doctor read an address on the Egyptian desert cure for nephritis.

Commenting on the recent death of Captain E.' St. G. Lowther, R.P.A., of the Egyptian Army, the "Army and Navy Gazette” says that he had lived more or less with his valise packed from the time he was posted to the regiment, and had seen service in West Africa and South Africa (during the war). He went to Egypt two years ago, and the character he bore for zenl and ability showed that he took his calling seriously and was desirous of making headway in it."

div.head:
EGYPT AND BABYLONIA.
PROF. FLINDERS PETRIES LECTURE.
div.p: The lecture, which was given last week at University College by Professor Flinders Pe. trie, marks the immense popular interest which is now being devoted to ancient Egypt and Babylonia. Not so very long ago an Egyptologist was looked upon rather as the near relation of his beloved mummies than as a sane human being. Now scarabe are popular subjects for pins and rings, and Egypt and Babylonia are being restored to their pristine glory. The progress of sociology is, of course, one of the factors in the Egyptian movement, and the discovery of the Rosetta stone gave the clue to the gold mine of information which the two civilizations furnished for ethical and social comparison. A little band of devoted students, among whom Professor Flinders Petrie holds a high rank, haa by translations and histories placed ancient Egypt and Babylonia within the reach of those who can now read the Book of the Dead and the Laws of Hammurabi without any knowledge of hieroglyphs or cuneiform inscriptions.

This lecture was the first of a course of lectures upon the civilization and conditions of the two oldest centres of culture, the river valleys of Egypt and Babylonia. The formation of the Nile Valley, he declared, was due to a great fault consequent on the np beaval, of the eastern desert, which rises, to 5,000ft, while the western winks below sea-level in the Fayoum and Sahara, Into this fault-line the drainage worked its way and gouged out a valley about 2,000ft. deep, the lower pact of which is filled up for goine hundreds of feet by debris now below sea level.

Upon this the Nile has deposited a coat of mohl since the rainfall ceased owing to the drying of the Sahara. This mad-bed is about 40ft) thick, and has grown about thin. a century during about 10,000 years But Egypt can not grow seawards, as the deposits are washed away in the Mediterranean as soon as they pass the shelter of the limestone cliffs of Alexandria and Canopus

The conditions are entirely different in Babylonia. In place of a rift valley trenched 2,000ft. deep the Babylonian plain is a long, wide synclinal trough of depression between the highlands of Arabin and Persia. The valley is essentially all one from its rise near the Black Sea down to the Straits of Hormuz, at the month of the Persian Gulf. The bed of this valley has been more than half submerged, up to the Balıylon; and the wash brought down has gradually filled it to the present const. In another 15,000 or 20,000 years it will fill up all that is now the Persian Gulf.

As all the material washed down falls into land-looked, still, shallow water it is not swept away, as in the Mediterranean, but is deposited, and gradually makes more land. The const, therefore, has moved south over two miles each century. Thus it is clear that the sites of the great cities of Babylonis were open son within the last 10,000 or 15,000 years.

div.head:
ALEXANDRIA SWIMMING CLUB
TOMORROWS AQUATIC SPORTS.
div.p: We remind our readers that tomorrow, commencing at 2.45 p.m. prompt, there will be held in the New Graving Dook, Gabbary, the fifth annual aquatic sports of the Alexandria Swimming Cluband of the most graciously extended patronage of his Highness the Khedive. We are also glad to announce that the meeting will be attended by H.B.M'. Consul General Gould and Mrs Gold, and that many other notables of the European communities of Alexandria and of the Native world have promised to be present. As for the sport to be witnessed, nothing can prevent this from being of the Keenest. A glance at Last year's programme, which was "in itself record olive, shows that the number of entries has increased for every event, and in many instances the list of competitors is considerably larger. The "form" shown by the competitors, too, at the weekly meetings of the club has been fully np to the mark, and the thoroughness of the handicapping guarantees as & succession of exciting fights for victory. The great event of the meeting, the 60 yards club handicap for the much-coveted Sirdar's medal, has aroused enormous interest and called forth 28 competitors, as compared with 20 last I year; it will be swum off as usual in four heats, the first two in ench of which will contest the final. Match humour and laughter is to be caused by "walking the pole," for, being in the know, we are able to say that the fancy costumes are more than ever. "screamingly funny," na the pierrots say, and most original. To detail the evetta, however, is impossible and we must be content with Assuring our readers that each will offer as good sport as one could wish to see. The club bonita amongst its members past champions of note in the amateur world of swimming, and who knows that budding champions may not swim the bath or cleave the water in groft dives to-morrow The muccess of former meetings has been great, but the sports of 1907 are going to well outstrip thom. Refreshments will be obtainable, the entering being in the bands of Walker and Meimarachi. A word of praise to Messrs. Waterlow Bros. and Layton, who have compiled the nestontana best programme yet published by the Club, Carriages should be ordered for 6 m. The Alexandria Tramway Company, Lal, has kindly organised a special tramway service from Rond Point to Gabbary for the community.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Anjourd'hui à midi)

C'est toujours le même groupe de titres qui bénéficie de la faveur de la spéoulation, voir la Building Lands, lo Comptoir, ls Cassa di Sconto et les Nungovich Hotels. A part oos derniers, qui ont été moins traités, les autres ont donné lieu à des échanges roulant sur 2 à 500 titres en tout pour chacun d'entre enx. quant aux valeurs dirigeantes, si l'on en excepte la Delta Light poar doux ou trois affaires, les autres ont été négligées. A signaler en Béhéra et en Union Foncière une demande qui n'a pas rencontre de contre-partieven deresse. Les Sidi Salomont aussi été demandées 2 13/32 - 7/16 sans affaires. En résumé la si tuation générale, comme on le voit resto la même, soit prix généralement soutenus et en hansso notable pour un petit groupe de valeurs, mais sans échanges appréciables, sauf pour le groupe en question. L'ancienne action Comptoir a touché 3 8/16 et s'y est maintenu; la nouvelle a passé du même coitp de 8 S.S. à 314 et la part de fondateur de 2 1/8 & 2 1/2 acheteurs. La Building Lands, après avoir atteint 2 5/16, a fini vendeurs à ce prix, ce qui représente 3/16 de hausse, En Cassa di Sconto on est allé jusqu'à 57 francs pour revenir en cloture & 54, contre 52 1/2 bier. Quant aux Nungovich Hotels après une ponssie A 19 1/16, ils ont fini à 18 3/4 vendenrs, par suite de la retraite des ache. teurs de la première heure. On attribue la reprise du Comptoir comme celle de la Cassa à la plus-value actuelle do son portefeuille qu'il n'a pas été contraint comme cette dernière de liquider en partie an plus mauvais moment. L'Agricole fléchit de 8 3/8 à 85/16, In NAtional Bank de 22 1/16 A 21 15/16, la Delte Laght de 10 3/8 & 10 5/16, les Privilégiées Tramways d'Alexandrie de 143 à 142 1/2 et la Differed Delta de 7 3/4 à 7 5/8, tandis que la Daira, plus en faveur, avance de 13 13 16 à 13 7/8, ainsi que la Béhéra de 21 7/8 & 92 1/4, l'Obligation Crédit Foncier de 302 1/9 &803 l'ancienne et de 255 1/2 a 257 la nouvelle, l'u. nion Foncière de 4 7/8 4 4 15/16. . Les petites valents, autres que celles dont nous avons déjà parle, sont négligées. Parmi elles, la Levant retrogrado do 19/88 * 9/26 vendenrs, l'United de 5 16 & 9/82 l'action et do 1 9/16 a 1 1/2 la fondatenr, les Ritz Hotels de 11/16 A 5/8. Sur le reste de la cote il n'y a pas de chan. gement à signaler. Il a été venda anx enchères publiques à la sonnce do oo matin 70 actions anciennes Comptoir Financier à 8 8/16, 25 actions Delta Land l11/16, 100 actions Helouan Development 18/16, et 3 parta de fondateur Levico à 9 9/16 Le mobilier des burennx de la Bourse and | Banking a été vendu hier par voie d'huissien

Nous détaehons de notre correspondance de Londres en date du 5 Octobre, les passages suivante :

Ostte dernière semaine, on s'est occupé plus quejmais des titres égyptiens, surtout de la National Bank qui a eu un marché très actif. Elle a fait 23 au plus haut, On attend beancoup du bonus que doit procurer à ce titre la nouvelle émission d'actions qui aura lieu sous pen.

"Quant la situation monétaire, elle resta en sormine Assuz favorable et il y a peu à crain, dre une nouvelle tension, les appels au crédit ne Yeussissant que si le taux d'intérêt rest très élevé, ce qui décourage les empruntours."

On annonce qu'un groupe d'actionnaires de la Bourse and Banking, mécontents de la décision prise par la dernière assemblée générale de liquider la Société à l'amiable, contestent les pouvoirs des liquidateurs jusqa'à approbation d'une nouvelle assemblée générale. Ils estiment que la décision a étè prise irré gulièrement ét ils veulent demander la liquidation judiciaire afin d'élucider la question des responsabilités.

On annonce de Londres que les actionnaires de l'Egyptian Gold and Gem Syndicate Ltd" fondée en Pévrier 1903 au capital de £ 36,230 en actions de £'1 complètement libérées, ont décidé la liquidation de la Société.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
Kearsley and Cunningham's Weekly Report
div.p: We have again to report a quiet market in Egyptian, the only change in quotations being 1/16 per lb advance in brown, whilst Uppers are unchanged.
In Futures only a limited business has been done, and following are the latest quotations:-

American Futures.The Market this week has been dull and featureless, with constant fluctuations of a few points either way. There has been less pressure to sell generally and to-days closing values are 7 1/2 to 1 points higher than those of last Thursday, the near positions having appreciated whilst the more distant positions have fallen to discounts. The Market having been too much depressed upon the Ginners and Bureau reports reached sharply, bur failed to maintain more than a partial improvement. We are now coming to the period when there will be considerable nervousness, a sudden fall in temperature, would with the considerable shortage existing in all the markets especially in New York and New Orleans, probably cause a sharp rise, but so far the article has failed to attract any important outside interest, due no doubt largely to the stringency of money, and the depressed condition of Stocks and Shares.

div.p: The Emperor's cough was too bad to permit of his receiving the Austrian and Hungarian Premiers to-day, as arranged. The latter has returned to Budapest, Uneasiness is felt regarding his Majesty's health.
(Reuter)
The Emperor contracted a cold at the manoeuvres which was aggravated by the strain of the recent prolonged audiences. There is every reason to hope for his Majesty's recovery.
(Reuter)
The state of the Emperor remains the same, but does not cause uneasiness.
(Havas)

THE TORRENTIAL RAINS.
HOUSES WASHED AWAY.
DELAY OF TRAFFIC.

div.p: Fresh torrential raids have fallen resulting in floods in the basins of the Rhone and Loire, Houses are being washed away. 5 persons have been killed due to the collapse of a hotel at Lepouzin, Arcidohe, and 9 others elsewhere. The trains between Paris and Marseilles are arriving. ing twelve hours late and are travelling by a círcuítous route. The Rhone is full of wreckage.
(Reuter)

div.head:
SUBMARINE MINES REGULATIONS.
NULIFIED BY RESERVATIONS.

div.p: The Conference has unanimously adopted the regulations governing submarine mines, but the reservations of several of the Powers practically nullify the most important provi. sions as far as they are concerned. These include Russia, Germany, France, and Siam. Sir E. Satow expressed regret that the British proposals limiting the area of mine laying had been rejected. The rights of neutrals, he considered, remain insufficiently guarded. Herr Bieberstein stated that Germany would only lay mines in cases of urgency.
(Reuter)
The press considers that the Austro-Russian note should have been presented to Athens alone. The conditions of the simultaneous presentation to Sofia and Belgrade are humiliating to the Slav races.
(Reuter)

Six thousand workmen made a demonstration in favour of universal suffrage. They sent a petition to the President of the Chamber, who assured them that Parliament will immediately consider the question.
(Havas)
The airship broke her moorings during a squall at the Crystal Palace and has been badly damaged. She is unable to return to Aldershot.
(Reuter)

Mr. Winston Churchill received an enthusiastic welcome here. Replying to addresses from the Greeks and Turks he said that he hoped to study the complicated problems of Cyprus. He proceeded to Nicosia as the guest of the Governor.
(Reuter)

div.head: EGYPT AND ISLAM
SAYYID EL-BERRI'S ESSAY
div.p: A highly interesting contribution on the subject of Egypt and Islam was made to the Church Congress last week by Professor Margoliouth, of New College, Oxford, who holds the position of Laudian Professor of Arabio. The Professor said a controversial challenge, an appeal to settle the conflicting claims of Islam and Christianity by argument, existed to some extent in Egypt; but it would be truer to say that the Moslems there had taken up the chal lenge of the Christian missionaries, and endeavonred to refute their objections to Islam. He should imagine, however, that such attacks on Christianity were far less common and far less often based on modern European theology in Egypt and Syria than in India. The challenge that attracted our attention was of a somewhat different sort. The reformers of Islam ir Egypt confessed - not unfrequently with exaggeration—that Moslems were both moral. ly and intellectually decadent, that Islam represented stagnation, and European civilization progress ; only they denied that Islam was the cause of thestagnation and Christianity the cause of the progress. The first writer whose opinions on this subject might be summarized was the Sayyid-al-Bekri, one of the best scholars and the most distinguished men in Cairo, who had within the last few months published an essay on the "Future of Islam." As the head of the religious orders he should have better opportunities of knowing about the progress and aspirations of his religion than anyone else ; it was, therefore, of great interest that he went for his facts almost entirely to french and English authorities : when he deserted these the facts appeared to be open to question, as where he stated that the number of Sufis was 100,000 millions, which was more than 50 times the whole population of the globe. He argued that Islam was shown to be the religion of the future by the vast increase which it exhibited in recent years, to which he proceeded to assign a variety of causes. Since the increase was chiefly in Egypt and India, and by births, not by conversions, the real cause appeared to be one that he had omitted -- viz., the excellence of British role; for in self-governing Moslem States no such increase appeared to be shown. The causes that he did state were: five, and they had been anticipated by European thinkers. They were the simplicity of Islam; the reasonableness of Islam; the skill of Moslem missionaries; the institntion de polygamy; and the dislike of pagan races to Europeans, due to caste distino|tion by colonr The European could not help trenting yellow races like servants and negroes like slaves. After stating these cases for the propagation of Islam, the Sayyid proceeded to I give an account of the political depression of Islam, and to suggest a remedy And here his treatment of the subject was similar to that of other Morlems who had dealt with the question. Ignorance was what depressed Islam, and teaching was the cure for it. Native Governments would not see to the proper instruction of the people, because they feared to roose the desire for equality; foreign Governments would not see to it for the same or a similar reason ;' it must be done by the enlightened Moslems themselves. The only way, then, was to found societies, whose concern should be the fature of Islaın, all grouped in a parent society, to hold its meetings in some central locality. We could only say let the Sayyid's experiment be tried ; instil into the minds of the Moslem youth the best moral and intelleotual notions, and let us see what the result would be for Islam. A reformed Islam had been preached for some nine years in a Caireno magazine called the "Besoon,” which was said to enjoy greater popularity than any other journal published in the Arabic language. The movement which it represented might be described as partly Protestant partly rationalistio in character ; its adherents maintained that Islam was decadent, because the Word of God (as they called the Koran) had been obscured by a mass of unauthorized tradition, which had oramped men's understandings and laden them with burdens too heavy to be borne. They advocated a return to the original revelation, and claimed the right to the free use of the reason in interpreting it. When in his last report Lord Cromer was supposed to attack the Moslem religion and charge it with standing in the way of progress, the Sayyid Rasbid, the editor of the "Beacon" and the leader of the reform party, wrote to ask his lordship whether his reference was to Islam in general, or to Islam as interpreted by the law schools, rightly supposing that his lordship's opinion would carry great weight in Earope and elsewhere. The reply was such as to confirm the doctrine preached in the "Beacon," that Islam was not in itself responsible for stagnation or reaction, but only the interpretation put on Islam by the or thodox exponents of its tenets. How far was the programme of the reformers of Islam identical in its practical effects--without reference to dogmas—with that of European missionaries, teaching the morality which we Associated with the Gospel, as interpreted by centaries of experience and observation The matter on which Christianity diverged most from Islam was the treatment of women. It was a pleasure to find that the reformers of Islam had not left this matter out of account, and that the equalization of the sexes was preached by some Moslems on the ground of the Koran and stranger still the Prophet's sayings and practice. The pjoneer in this most necessary reform was Kasim Bey Amin, whose works on the "Emapoipation of Women" and The New Woman" had been favourably received. He made ont a list of woman's wrongs which cried for redress, and placed among them the practices of polygamy and concubinage, which we, most of us, associated with the names of the Islamic Prophet and his religion. To find a Moslem who asserted that he would not entertain any doctrine contradicted by the Koran, condemning poly gamy, was surely a most hopeful sign for the regeneration of the East, Kasim Boy Amin gave us the cheering information that in Egypt during the last 20 or 30 yeårs-i.e., since the British occupation--the practice of polygamy had been steadily decreasing, and the seclusion of women vastly modified. The continuance of these institutions he held to be impossible they were doomed by the force of circumstances; his purpose was to popularise and hasten the spread of the reform, and to prove it to be in harmony with the spirit of Islam. To take one other matter, religious toleration, it would be contrary to the experience of mankind if the magnificent toleration exhibited by Great Britain--under whose administration the mosques were better cared for than ever before-had not met with some response. The signs of such were to be looked for in the attitnde of Islam towards Oriental Christianity rather than European Christianity, which was, of course, associated with power and knowledge. And such signs were not wanting. Last De. cember, when the foremost Christian Arabic scholar in Cairo was removed by death, warm tributes to his merits appeared in many Moslem journals; and a Christian now resident in Cairo was regarded by Moslems or at least by many of them as one of the foremost, -it not actually the chief, Arabic writer of the time. He had been told that sabsoriptions from Moslemns towards, new churcbes, and from Christians towards new mosques, were common events in fashionable circles. If it be asked, in view of these facts, where did missionary work come in, it might be replied that where there was much work to be done, where we were faced by problems to which & completo solution could not be found, pradence suggested the encouragement of a variety of agencies. Even the controversy which prosélytizing work provoked probably led many to use their thinking pbwers in estimating the claims of rival creeds. Bat a reform of Islam from within must necessarily be more efficacious than anything which could be attempted from the outside. The creation of mutual respect between the two communities or groups of communities was essential before the amalgamation of the one with the other could be dreamed of. And it, as the years proceeded, the chief thinkers of Islam still found, as they did now, that their religion was everywhere nocompanied by intellectual and moral stagnation, that their efforts at raising their country. men on the basis of the Koran were futile, perhaps they would determine that that basis must be abandoned, and that the sources of enlightenment must be the same for them as for Europe.

div.head: Sudan Government
NOTICE.
div.p: Persons importing Egyptian Labourers to work in the Sudan are recommended to enter into a written contract with them. This contract should be explained and signed by the Labourers in the presence of an official ot other reliable witness.

div.head: MINISTRY OF PUBLIC INSTRUCTION
THE LAMBERT AFFAIR.
div.p: The following letter has been published in the "Temps" from Mr. Lambert:

I have hitherto refrained from supplying food to the polemics aroused by my resignation, because I was not entirely free from the bonds of my-Egyptian fonctions. I have now recovered my freedom of speech and am glad to profit thereby in order to make known the reasons which constrained me to abandon the management of the Khedivial School of Law.

I renounced this position not without a real pang, because the place was suoh as a man of science conld not retain ; because I could maintain myself in this well paid situation only on the condition of being the blind instru. ment of a policy as incorrect, as it was compromising for the cordiality of the relations existing between natives and Europeans.

The English functionary who has the effective control of the Ministry of Public Instruction, Mr. Douglas Donlop, daring the year which preceded my arrival in Cairo, had already with rare perseverance undermined the authority of the director, and taken advantage of the moment when this authority was reduced to nothing, to exasperate the students by measures both brutal and useless, thus provoking a strike which had furnished him with the opportunity of venting his rancor against my predecessor. I was not treated any better. The English Adviser raised np for me inextricable embarrassments by wilful or involuntary blunders, of which I could not avert the consequences, being closely bound by regulations which took away from me all, even the technical, control of my establishment, and handed it over to the offices of the Ministry.

Mr. Danlop has blindly combatted the development of French culture in a school, whose teaching nevertheless is and will remain, as long as the legislation of the country is not completely revolutionized, a tenching of French law, because the Egyptian codes are only reductions of onr own, and because with the exception of some rare monographs they have inspired no original literature. He organised in this establishment a veritable parody of higher education, while abstaining from preserving the fixed staff of the French section, on the plea that it was destined shortly to disappear, and expelling from the most frequented section, that in which French law is taught in the English language, the excellent collaborators of long standing, the magistrates whom a long sojourn in the country had habi. tuated to the mechanism of our law, to replace them by young fellows appointed on their leaving an English University, who disembark in Egypt as ignorant of the principles of jurisprudence in force in the country ng the students whom they are charged to instruct, and some of whom have not at the present moment become sufficiently acquainted with our language to translate accurately the manvals from which they derive the notes for their lectures.

I have seen broken one by one, before the disdainful resistance of the advisor, all my efforts to improve the professional culture of this staff, by making them specialise, by removing from their shoulders a number of courses whose preparation was materially impossible, by developing emulation through the attraction of advancement by choice, by removing the causes which induced the English "mistress" to leave the school before they had learned sufficient French law to be able to force the --doors of the Egyptian magistrature.

While a prudent and benevolent practice of discipline would have been necessary to avoid exasperating the legitimate discontent caused by this decadence of teaching among a body of students whom the movement of intellectual awakening which is arousing their country at this moment has galvanised and rendered avid of culture, Mr. Danlop has subjected students arrived at the age of manhood, often married, sometimes fathers of families, to the same disciplinary regulations as the children in the primary schools, and has adopted in their regard a policy of pin pricks and patty persecu. tions. The result of this procedure was to throw into the arms of the anti-English opposition the intellectual élite who were being prepared by their education to become a factor of perce and of Europeanisation ; to engender in the hearts of these young men a hatred of the British administration, and to transform the School of Law into a veritable seminary of Egyptian nationalism, so that among an actual attendance of 400 pupils, one would with difficulty find a dozen not entirely devoted to the doctrines of Moustafa Kamel Pasha. In vain have I essayed to open the eyes of the British Adviser to the dangers of his system of educational rnle. I have been able to obtain from him no more than momentary concessions, and never the sincere and definite abandonment of his regime of systematic vexations and anhoyanoes. I could not under these condi. tions dissimulate the fact that the irritative action of Mr. Danlop would sooner or later produce the explosion in my school of new tempests more redoubtable than that which had burst forth in 1906, and for which I was in danger of being made responsible by Egyptian opinion

Mo Dunlop, in fine, submitted my dignity to a very painful trial, in reserving for me and despite myself a role in the mystifications which he organizes against a native minister F. E. Sand Pasha Zaghlool, who having been appointed by the British Agency under the pressure of public opinion has not been content to remain a simple manikin. To reduce this spoil-sport to impotence the English Adviser compelled the principal functionation of the Ministry of Public Instruction to join in forming a sort of league intended to parylene the action of their official chief. I was not authorised any more than my collongues to remain neutral. Alter dictating to me the out. line of my official reports, Mr. Dunlop obliged me to submit them to his corrections before addressing them to the minister; sometimes even I had to altor after the event, and according to the indications of the Adviser's documents alrendy issued from my Office and registered in the Ministry. These acts of compliance, already very annoying, were considered insufici. ent. To remain longer the collaborator of Mr. Dunlop I should have to consent to a sacrifice of conscience more humiliating still, and to expose myself to the risks of being caught at every-instant, in flagrante delicts" of betrayal, by H.E. Sand Pasha Zaghlool. My relations with Mr. Dunlop who, for the various reasons I have already enumerated, showed towards me marked signs of unfriendliness, became more difficult on account of a disagreement as to the recruitment of professors.

In order to replace three professors who were leaving and so as to provide for an increase in the number of technical classes according to a new law which had been promulgated, I was obliged to ask for the engagement for 1907-8 of at least two new collaborators. After having promised me formarly to give his permission, Mr. Dunlop withdrew his acquiescence because the turn politics were taking did not allow him to import further European professors, and because he would on no account allow the intrusion of Egyptians in the teaching staff of the school.

I refused to agree with this excuse "cette fin de non recevoir tardive" and I was able, thanks to a highly-placed English official, to impose upon Mr. Danlop the nomination of two Egyptian tenchers. Although in order to obtain this result, I was obliged to give my consent to important concessions and, above all, to agree to give an unfavorable report concerning all the candidates who might apply for admission as teachers in response to the Appeal the Minister of Public Instruction bad minde in the "Journal Officiel" for the collabor ation of Egyptians, Mr. Dunlop never forgave me this act of independence. He submitted me in my turn to the policy of "bullying" with which my predecessor had already been acquainted.

Then it was that, having used np my last means of Defence and convinced that I chald no longer do anything to protect my staff and my students against the Adviser's anger. I resigned myself to the eventuality of an-early departure. A joke of a particularly doubtful character, and which thanks to the publicity given it by Mr Dunlop, did not enable me to endure it without losing all consideration in the eyes of my collaborators or pupils, hastened my de. cision, I tendered my resignation. It was Accepted with enthusiasm and the following day already, I was replaced by an English professor, whose right to succeed mo has been concretely defined in a sentence attributed either tightly or wrongly to Sir Bldon Gorst : "Mr. Hill is an ignoramus; all the better, he will be docile." Some of my compatriots in Cairo reproached me for having sacrificed the superior interests of France to satisfy the soraples of my conscience, abandoning, with a view to avoid accomplishing a task which appeared to me to be repugnant, one of the highest posts in Egyptian educational institutions, and one which up to the present had been monopolised by Frenchmen. I cannot agree with their particular conception of French interests. As regards French interests in the East, they were furthered by men like Vidal Pasha and Testoud who governed the Khedivial School of Law when the directors had their hands free and could work for the propagation of our juridical science. But the upholding of our prestige in Egypt can only be compromised if French university professors consent to hide beneath the folds of their togas, the work of intel." lectual strangulation pursued by Mr. Danlop. Nor must we dissimulate that we have no chance of being able to conserve a representation however menger on the educational staffs of official Egyptian institutions. A few years agd we would still have been able to defend ourselves. To-day it is too late. Oor defeat has been accomplished and last triomph has crowned the anti-French policy of Mr. Dunlop, by the recent publication of a Khedivial deoree definitely suppressing the first year of French in the only secondary school in Cairo where it still existed, namely the Towfikieh School. 1 Consequently, in four years French will have disappeared as a teaching medium in all Government establishments, and the liquidation of the French section in the Khedivial School of Law will have begun. We cannot, as regards the future, maintain our intellectual influence except by the exploit. tation in our free educational institutions of the errors of the British school policy. We possess in Cairo a French law-school. In order to attract to its classes the immense majority of the notable pupils of the Khedivial School of Law, it would be sufficient to harmonise our curricula and our methods with the national requirements of Egypt, to utilise Egyptians of competence, especially specialists in Moslem law, to send official examiners such as are sent to our Medical College in Beyrouth and to organise preparatory French classes, It is very improbable that we shall ever be able to find a more propitious opportunity for reconstituting the monopoly of Law.eduon tion which was torn from onr hands in 1899.
